docs.lead_paragraph: In a speech meant to echo John F. Kennedy's 1961 challenge to the nation to put a man on the moon ''before this decade is out,'' President Clinton plans to use a commencement address on Sunday to call for scientists to develop an AIDS vaccine within the next 10 years. Yet unlike Mr. Kennedy, who said the race into space could require billions of dollars, Mr. Clinton is not expected to call for a new infusion of Federal money into the research effort.

headline.main: Clinton Assembles a List of Kennedyesque Challenges

docs.lead_paragraph: At times, the many people who love Matthew Gross can almost believe that the nightmare of the last three months is nearing an end. He will greet them in his room at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in East Orange, N.J., with a cascade of pleasantries, or grab his guitar and strum the chords of Bruce Springsteen's ''Born to Run,'' and for a few moments, it is as if the shooting atop the Empire State Building has finally loosened its clutch. But then reality reasserts itself, in quirky and subtle ways.

headline.main: A World Remade by Empire State Gunfire

docs.abstract: Special report, Starting Over, describes recovery of Matthew Gross, who suffered severe brain injuries in February 1997 shooting by Palestinian, Ali Abu Kamal, on observation deck of Empire State Building; recovery has been odyssey of uncertainty for members of family, who have been forced to confront vagaries of traumatic brain injury, which can leave some skills intact and others in tatters; photos (L)
docs.snippet: At times, the many people who love Matthew Gross can almost believe that the nightmare of the last three months is nearing an end.    He will greet them in his room at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in East Orange, N.J., with a cascade of...

docs.lead_paragraph: ON Thursday, Denis Gibbs will don cap and gown to receive a Bachelor of Arts degree from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Soon after he completes his four-year college journey, he will begin another long trip: paying off, over 10 years, a six-figure accumulation of loans. Mr. Gibbs, 22, is hardly without resources. He is ambitious and smart, having made Phi Beta Kappa while majoring in international studies and German. And he has landed a job on Wall Street, at Smith Barney, where he will be paid a salary in the mid-$30,000 range, plus the potential for bonuses, to help evaluate the performance of the firm's divisions. He plans to begin work on July 7.

headline.main: Graduating With Honors And $100,000 in Debt

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past several years, a select group of the nation's biggest corporations have given millions of dollars to the National Governors' Association and an affiliated research arm. In return for their tax-deductible contributions, the corporations' lobbyists have gained unusual access to the governors' policy-making apparatus. They take part in the governors' plenary meetings, attend receptions with governors, get briefings from the group's leaders and staff, are offered private work spaces and meeting areas at its annual gatherings and attend other events to help them ''become better acquainted with governors' staffs and to share common interests,'' an association fact sheet says.

headline.main: CORPORATE GIFTS HELP GAIN ACCESS TO U.S. GOVERNORS

docs.abstract: Number of major corporations have over past few years given millions of dollars in tax-deductible contributions to National Governors' Assn and affiliated research group and, in return, received unusual access to governors' policy-making apparatus; lobbyists take part in plenary meetings, attend receptions with governors, get briefings from leaders and staff and are offered private work spaces at annual meetings; corporations include AT&T, Exxon, General Motors, Dow Chemical, Pfizer, Blue Cross/Blue Shield, Philip Morris and Goldman Sachs; association, which actively recruited corporate 'fellows,' defends ties as way to get best advice on important issues, but critics see unfair advantage over adversaries such as labor unions and advocacy groups, which were not invited; results are illustrated at April meeting of natural resources committee, when corporate fellows joined discussion of electricity and environmental issues; Gregory F Wetstone of Natural Resources Defense Council recalls surprise at finding lobbyists already there when he was asked to join session; Gov Tommy Thompson says critics are 'off base,' and that money is being raised for organization's Center for Best Practices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of many top American companies, the Democratic National Committee said today that it would offer same-sex partners the same health benefits available to spouses of its employees. Single-sex marriage has not been legalized, so such benefit offerings are not required by law. Nevertheless, approximately 500 companies, including Microsoft, the International Business Machines Corporation, the Walt Disney Company, Apple Computer and Time-Warner, offer health benefits to domestic partners of their employees. In addition, numerous cities, counties and universities offer similar programs.

headline.main: Democrats Give Health Benefits To Gay Couples

docs.abstract: Democratic National Committee will offer same-sex partners same health benefits available to spouses of employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. said its president, Joseph Sebastianelli, resigned, effective June 1, after serving a little more than two months in the job. Mr. Sebastianelli's responsibilities will be assumed by the chairman and chief executive, Ronald E. Compton. Mr. Sebastianelli, 50, was promoted to his position in March as part of the insurance company's efforts to build its health care business. Before becoming president, he served as co-president of Aetna U.S. Healthcare and executive vice president of the company. The executive cited personal reasons for his departure. A company spokeswoman said Mr. Sebastianelli would not remain with the company and had not disclosed his plans. Shares in Hartford-based Aetna fell $2.125, to $94.75.

headline.main: PRESIDENT OF AETNA RESIGNS FOR PERSONAL REASONS

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc says its president, Joseph Sebastianelli, rsigned, effective June 1, after serving a little more than two months in job; personal reasons cited for departure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After two weeks of haggling and a day of high-level negotiating, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, announced this evening that Congressional Republicans and the White House had agreed in writing to the details of their balanced budget deal. He said he expected Congress to approve a budget resolution within a week. The written plan and accompanying letters of agreement signed by Senator Lott and Speaker Newt Gingrich, on which the Administration insisted, hold fast to the broad framework that the Republican leaders and President Clinton agreed to two weeks ago.

headline.main: Clinton and G.O.P. Spell Out Details for Balanced Budget

docs.abstract: Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott announces that Congressional Republicans and Clinton Administration have agreed in writing to the details of their balanced budget deal, and he expects Congress to approve budget resolution within a week; written plan and accompanying letter of agreement, signed by Lott and Speaker Newt Gingrich, as demanded by the Administration, hold fast to the broad framework that Republican leadership and Pres Clinton agreed to two weeks ago (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is taking some jabs at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani because the Mayor, who likes to boast that he has made city workers far more productive, does not want to negotiate with the police union about increased police productivity. The union, representing 29,000 police officers, is demanding that the city negotiate over how savings from increased police productivity should go toward raises for the police.

headline.main: Union Cites Productivity As an Issue In Police Pact

docs.abstract: Patrolmen's Benevolent Association criticizes Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani because he does not want to negotiate with union about increased police productivity; union is demanding that city negotiate over how savings from increased productivity should go toward raises for police (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House tonight followed the Senate in passing an emergency $8.4 billion spending bill spurred by floods in the Dakotas, despite a White House veto threat directed at a provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns in budget fights. The bill was passed 244 to 178, with 175 Republicans and 69 Democrats voting for it and 46 Republicans, 131 Democrats and 1 independent voting no. Its major items are $5.5 billion for disaster relief and $2 billion for international peacekeeping.

headline.main: House Passes Disaster Aid, With Wrinkle

docs.abstract: House, 244-178, passes emergency $8.4 billion spending bill spurred by floods in Dakotas despite White House veto threat directed at provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns in budget fights (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The doctor turned entrepreneur who brought for-profit cancer care to New York City is planning a new profit-making health care venture for the city: a chain of AIDS and H.I.V. treatment centers. The doctor, Bernard Salick, who was removed as the head of the cancer and kidney care centers he founded after a British drug manufacturer bought the company in April, said his main adviser on the new project would be Dr. David Ho, one of the world's pre-eminent AIDS researchers and the person credited with developing the ''cocktail'' drug treatment that has benefited many AIDS patients.

headline.main: Entrepreneur Plans to Open Profit-Making AIDS Centers
